com.jayway.restassured.config

Class SSLConfig

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.jayway.restassured.config.SSLConfig

  • public class SSLConfig
extends Object
    Configure SSL for REST Assured.

    The following documentation is taken from http://groovy.codehaus.org/modules/http-builder/doc/ssl.html:

    SSL Configuration

    SSL should, for the most part, "just work." There are a few situations where it is not completely intuitive. You can follow the example below, or see HttpClient's SSLSocketFactory documentation for more information.

    SSLPeerUnverifiedException

    If you can't connect to an SSL website, it is likely because the certificate chain is not trusted. This is an Apache HttpClient issue, but explained here for convenience. To correct the untrusted certificate, you need to import a certificate into an SSL truststore.

    First, export a certificate from the website using your browser. For example, if you go to https://dev.java.net in Firefox, you will probably get a warning in your browser. Choose "Add Exception," "Get Certificate," "View," "Details tab." Choose a certificate in the chain and export it as a PEM file. You can view the details of the exported certificate like so: 

     $ keytool -printcert -file EquifaxSecureGlobaleBusinessCA-1.crt
 Owner: CN=Equifax Secure Global eBusiness CA-1, O=Equifax Secure Inc., C=US
 Issuer: CN=Equifax Secure Global eBusiness CA-1, O=Equifax Secure Inc., C=US
 Serial number: 1
 Valid from: Mon Jun 21 00:00:00 EDT 1999 until: Sun Jun 21 00:00:00 EDT 2020
 Certificate fingerprints:
 MD5:  8F:5D:77:06:27:C4:98:3C:5B:93:78:E7:D7:7D:9B:CC
 SHA1: 7E:78:4A:10:1C:82:65:CC:2D:E1:F1:6D:47:B4:40:CA:D9:0A:19:45
 Signature algorithm name: MD5withRSA
 Version: 3
 ....
    Now, import that into a Java keystore file: 
     $ keytool -importcert -alias "equifax-ca" -file EquifaxSecureGlobaleBusinessCA-1.crt -keystore truststore_javanet.jks -storepass test1234
 Owner: CN=Equifax Secure Global eBusiness CA-1, O=Equifax Secure Inc., C=US
 Issuer: CN=Equifax Secure Global eBusiness CA-1, O=Equifax Secure Inc., C=US
 Serial number: 1
 Valid from: Mon Jun 21 00:00:00 EDT 1999 until: Sun Jun 21 00:00:00 EDT 2020
 Certificate fingerprints:
 MD5:  8F:5D:77:06:27:C4:98:3C:5B:93:78:E7:D7:7D:9B:CC
 SHA1: 7E:78:4A:10:1C:82:65:CC:2D:E1:F1:6D:47:B4:40:CA:D9:0A:19:45
 Signature algorithm name: MD5withRSA
 Version: 3
 ...
 Trust this certificate? [no]:  yes
 Certificate was added to keystore
    Now you want to use this truststore in your client: 
     RestAssured.config = RestAssured.newConfig().sslConfig(new SSLConfig("/truststore_javanet.jks", "test1234");
    or 
     given().config(newConfig().sslConfig(new SSLConfig("/truststore_javanet.jks", "test1234")). ..

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      SSLConfig()
      Creates a new SSL Config instance with the following settings: No keystore No password KeyStore.getDefaultType() No explicit default port No trust store No SSLSocketFactory SSLSocketFactory.STRICT_HOSTNAME_VERIFIER as X509HostnameVerifier implementation

    • Constructor Detail

      • SSLConfig

        public SSLConfig()
        Creates a new SSL Config instance with the following settings:
        • No keystore
        • No password
        • KeyStore.getDefaultType()
        • No explicit default port
        • No trust store
        • No SSLSocketFactory
        • SSLSocketFactory.STRICT_HOSTNAME_VERIFIER as X509HostnameVerifier implementation

    • Method Detail

      • keystore

        public SSLConfig keystore(String pathToJks,
                 String password)
        Parameters:
        pathToJks - The path to the JKS. REST Assured will first look in the classpath and if not found it will look for the JKS in the local file-system
        password - The store pass
        Returns:
        A new SSLConfig instance

      • keystore

        public SSLConfig keystore(File pathToJks,
                 String password)
        Use a keystore located on the file-system. See keystore(String, String) for more details.
        Parameters:
        pathToJks - The path to JKS file on the file-system
        password - The password for the keystore
        Returns:
        The request specification
        See Also:
        keystore(String, String)

      • keystore

        public SSLConfig keystore(String password)
        Uses the user default keystore stored in <user.home>/.keystore
        Parameters:
        password - - Use null for no password
        Returns:
        The keystore specification

      • keystoreType

        public SSLConfig keystoreType(String keystoreType)
        The certificate type, will use KeyStore.getDefaultType() by default.
        Parameters:
        keystoreType - The keystore type.
        Returns:
        A new SSLConfig instance

      • port

        public SSLConfig port(int port)
        The port for which REST Assured will apply the SSL configuration. This is advanced configuration and most of the time you do not need to specify a port since REST Assured will apply the configuration to the https port defined in the URI.
        Parameters:
        port - port.
        Returns:
        A new SSLConfig instance

      • trustStore

        public SSLConfig trustStore(KeyStore trustStore)
        A trust store to use during SSL/Certificate authentication.
        Parameters:
        trustStore - The trust store to use.
        Returns:
        A new SSLConfig instance

      • relaxedHTTPSValidation

        public SSLConfig relaxedHTTPSValidation()
        Use relaxed HTTP validation. This means that you'll trust all hosts regardless if the SSL certificate is invalid. By using this method you don't need to specify a keystore (see keystore(String, String) or trust store (see trustStore(java.security.KeyStore).
        Returns:
        A new SSLConfig instance

      • sslSocketFactory

        public SSLConfig sslSocketFactory(org.apache.http.conn.ssl.SSLSocketFactory sslSocketFactory)
        Specify a SSLSocketFactory. This will override settings from trust store as well as keystore and password.
        Parameters:
        sslSocketFactory - The SSLSocketFactory to use.
        Returns:
        A new SSLConfig instance

      • x509HostnameVerifier

        public SSLConfig x509HostnameVerifier(org.apache.http.conn.ssl.X509HostnameVerifier x509HostnameVerifier)
        Provide a custom X509HostnameVerifier implementation that'll be used by the SSLSocketFactory. You can replace the X509HostnameVerifier for example if you want to allow all host names etc.
        Parameters:
        x509HostnameVerifier - The X509HostnameVerifier to use.
        Returns:
        A new SSLConfig instance
        See Also:
        allowAllHostnames(), strictHostnames()

      • strictHostnames

        public SSLConfig strictHostnames()
        Configure the SSLConfig to use strict host name verification (this is the default behavior).
        Returns:
        A new SSLConfig instance
        See Also:
        SSLSocketFactory.STRICT_HOSTNAME_VERIFIER

      • allowAllHostnames

        public SSLConfig allowAllHostnames()
        Configure the SSLConfig to allow all host names.
        Returns:
        A new SSLConfig instance
        See Also:
        SSLSocketFactory.ALLOW_ALL_HOSTNAME_VERIFIER

      • sslConfig

        public static SSLConfig sslConfig()
        Returns:
        A static way to create a new SSLConfig instance without calling "new" explicitly. Mainly for syntactic sugar.

        Syntactic sugar.
        Returns:
        The same SSL config instance.

      • isUserConfigured

        public boolean isUserConfigured()
        Returns:
